instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.D6990: What is D6990? Diode sitting between PPBUS_G3H/PP18V5 charger voltage and PP3V42_G3H power supply input, can die and cause PP3V42_G3H to be missing and have no input voltage. .
definitions.A1278: What is A1278? A1278 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook or Macbook Pro Unibody from years Late 2008, Mid 2009, Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011, Mid 2012 with EMC 2254, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2327, 820-2530, 820-2879, 820-2936, 820-3115..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.R6990: What is R6990? Resistor between charger voltage and input to PP3V42_G3H power supply on Macbooks from around the year 2012. This resistor blows when C6990 has shorted to ground or U6990 has shorted to ground, and will result in PP3V42_G3H missing and the magsafe charger not having a light since PP3V42_G3H is necessary for the SMC to turn on and the onewire circuit to turn on..
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.CHGR_ACOK: What is CHGR_ACOK? This is identical to SMC_BC_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.SMBUS_BATT_SCL: What is SMBUS_BATT_SCL? SMBUS_BATT_SCL is the clock line of an I2C data line between the battery charging chip that creates PPBUS_G3H, the system management controller(SMC), the battery, and the battery indicator LED..
definitions.R5280: What is R5280? Pullup resistor between PP3V42_G3H and SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA which is a data line that allows the SMC to communicate with the battery and the battery charging chip. This line is necessary for the battery to be recognized. With red probe on ground, diode mode should measure 0.441 on pin 2 of this resistor. .
definitions.R5281: What is R5281? Pullup resistor between PP3V42_G3H and SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL which is a data line that allows the SMC to communicate with the battery and the battery charging chip. This line is necessary for the battery to be recognized. With red probe on ground, diode mode should measure 0.441 on pin 2 of this resistor. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Does Not Regognize Battery
threads.message: Hi Guys, I have a 2012 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) That had Very slight Water Damage around the <TRANSISTOR>Q5480</TRANSISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R5481</RESISTOR> Area. After Cleaning the area It still Had No Green Light so I Replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and Now it Runs Perfectly Off the Charger But does not recognize Battery and there is no orange Light...I checked the Board For any Corrosion under the Microscope and all looks good...I am also Getting 12.23v at F7040 wIth adapter Present and 11.98v With just the Battery...3.4V on both Pin1 and 2 of L6995...I also removed <CAPACITOR>C6400</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C6405</CAPACITOR>...I am Getting 0.4v resistance between Pins 17/18 on <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>...So far I have Replaced...<CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R6990</RESISTOR>, <DIODE>D6990</DIODE>, <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>, And <RESISTOR>R5087</RESISTOR>...Any ideas?...Thank You

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Does Not Regognize Battery
threads.message: Correction...I meant I get 0.04ohms Between pin 17/18 on <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Does Not Regognize Battery
threads.message:
Pin 17-18 0.04 ohms between them, it looks like your pins are shorting together, make sure <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is properly soldered and check again resistance between pins 17-18. It should be close to 2.2-4.5ohms.

If <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> doesn't run well it will not output <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> (<SIGNAL>CHGR_ACOK</SIGNAL>) and this will prevent light on magsafe even if you have 3.42V on L6995.

12,23V instead of 12,60V with charger is an indication that smc is not running because it's bad or because <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is not sending required signals to smc.

<CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is talking with smc, if data lines are messed it will not recognize battery. (See page 48)

Could be also crap Under SMC but I would first adress <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> for magsafe light and correct reading on pins 17-18.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Does Not Regognize Battery
threads.message:
Check diode mode on both data pins to the battery <SIGNAL>SMBUS_BATT_SCL</SIGNAL> and SDA.

Battery indicator disconnected to rule out that is giving issues? <RESISTOR>R5280</RESISTOR>/81 checked?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Does Not Regognize Battery
threads.message: Replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> Again and I am getting 3.4ohms on Pin 17/18 now...I have a Green Light on Charger But it Still is not recognizing the Battery and I am  still getting 12.26v On F7040 with Charger attatched and 11.98v with Just the Battery attached. I Also removed the Rubber Around the Corners of the SMC Chip Cleaned all around the perimeter the Fluxed and heated the SMC...I measured <SIGNAL>SMBUS_BATT_CSL</SIGNAL> and SDA lines and get 2.39 in Diode Mode...<RESISTOR>R5281</RESISTOR>/80 giving Proper Mesurements also. Also I did replace <RESISTOR>R5087</RESISTOR> Prior to getting a Green Light with a resistor that is 470k 5% 1/16w 220 instead of a 1/20w as that was all I had...Could that make a Difference on not seeing the Battery? And last but not least I have Not put <CAPACITOR>C6409</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C6405</CAPACITOR> Back on the Board yet JUST IN CASE they were the reason for not getting a green light in the beginning...The computer Runs Great off the Charger But still no Battery...I feel like I'm SO CLOSE!!!..lol...Anything else I can try?. Thank You in advance for Your Help. :)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Does Not Regognize Battery
threads.message:
Correction...I Meant I replaced <RESISTOR>R5087</RESISTOR> Which is a..........(470K/5%/120W/201) Resistor

With a (470K/5%/1/16W/201) Resistor.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Does Not Regognize Battery
threads.message: Also...What should the Proper Diode readings be  for data lines SMBUS_ <SIGNAL>BATT_SCL</SIGNAL> & SDA?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Does Not Regognize Battery
threads.message:
2.39 is not a diode mode measurement. It will in normal cases never be over 1.0. Typical measurement is somewhere between 0.300 and 0.700 for data lines. 
I'm pretty sure your SMC is dead.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Does Not Regognize Battery
threads.message: Thank Tou for the Quick Response Duke :) With the Red Probe on ground and Black probe on Pin 4, Pin 6 of the Battery Connector I get 2.399kohms on each pin with the Multimeter set to Diode Mode?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Does Not Regognize Battery
threads.message:
You're measuring voltage drop in diode mode, so it cant be the figure stated in ohms.

Anyway, replace the SMC.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Does Not Regognize Battery
threads.message: I am going to also check those 2 Data lines coming off of <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> also...Anything else I can check?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Does Not Regognize Battery
threads.message: You could use a scope and check the signalling on the data lines,

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Does Not Regognize Battery
threads.message: Unfortunately I Don't have a Scope...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Does Not Regognize Battery
threads.message: Is there anywhere that I can Pirchase a Preballed SMC for this model? I don't have a stencil of Balls...InDO have another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board but I can't renal the SMC chip once I remove it...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Does Not Regognize Battery
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Does Not Regognize Battery
threads.message: Forget about "new" SMCs. Take one from a donor board and reball it. Get the stencil and practice on a few trash SMCs. Use search on the forum there is a link to the Ebay auction for the stencil somewhere.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Does Not Regognize Battery
threads.message: Okay...Thank You Duke!!!..I will search around on eBay for one...I appreciate Everyone's Help....Thanks Again :)
